page.title: 15Tenements in Edinburgh
page.content: Tenement Housing started in the{Old {Town} of Edinburgh in the Middle Ages. The 'high rise' buildings eventually reached to over 12 storeys and were among the tallest buildings in Europe in the 17th century. The burghers of Edinburgh built 'up' rather than 'out' due to a wish to stay within the security of the city walls. All social classes lived in these overcrowded and often unsafe buildings. When building commenced in the Newington, Marchmont and Bruntsfield areas in the 19th century, the tenements of the Old Town were the inspiration, but these new tenements were lower, around 5 storeys, and more spacious, with large airy rooms, bay windows, high ceilings and intricate plasterwork cornices. These flats are in demand because of their solid stone construction and central location.
